docs.lead_paragraph: Falling-down drunk, as the expression has it, is the kind of condition that on its face would seem to require little in the way of explanation. One drinks too much, one tries to stand up, one does not succeed. The rest is history. But researchers at the Mayo Clinic in Minnesota, seeking insights into broader questions about how the brain and the nervous system control blood pressure and the heart, decided to study how alcohol could knock people off their feet.

headline.main: When Alcohol Knocks You Off Your Feet

docs.abstract: Researchers at Mayo Clinic study how alcohol can knock people off their feet; find that alcohol, combined with stress caused when one stands up, could cause drop in blood pressure, even among young people who drank relatively moderate amount (S)
docs.snippet: Falling-down drunk, as the expression has it, is the kind of condition that on its face would seem to require little in the way of explanation. One drinks too much, one tries to stand up, one does not succeed. The rest is history.    But researchers...

docs.lead_paragraph: Ask the average social scientist why people become criminals, and the answer is apt to center on poverty and abuse, not brain structure and neurochemicals. But in a new study, appearing in the February issue of the Archives of General Psychiatry, researchers report that 21 men with antisocial personality disorder, a psychiatric diagnosis often applied to people with a history of criminal behavior, and a history of violence had subtle abnormalities in the structure of the brain's frontal lobe.
docs.abstract: Twenty-one men with antisocial personality disorder and a history of violence are found to have subtle abnormalities in structure of brain's frontal lobe; researchers find that abnormalities distinguished men with disorder from healthy subjects, as well as from subjects who abused alcohol or drugs, or who suffered from other psychiatric disorders like schizophrenia (M)
docs.snippet: Ask the average social scientist why people become criminals, and the answer is apt to center on poverty and abuse, not brain structure and neurochemicals.    But in a new study, appearing in the February issue of the Archives of General Psychiatry,...

docs.lead_paragraph: ''I Love You, You're Perfect, Now Change.'' The title of this long-running off-Broadway show sums up the source of most marital problems. All too often, the very characteristics that initially attracted partners to one another or the disturbing behaviors that at first were ignored or considered unimportant eventually become marital sore points and the cause of repeated arguments and chronic unhappiness. Couples struggle to get one another to change -- to conform to each other's needs and desires and definition of a more perfect partner. ''Why don't you . . . ?'' ''Why can't you . . . ?'' ''Why aren't you . . . ?'' and ''You're wrong . . .'' are common pleas and criticisms that are more likely to precipitate arguments than change. Anger, accusations and attempts at coercion do not inspire compassion and cooperation, and rarely do couples who use this approach succeed on their own in exacting the desired changes.

headline.main: A Matter of Compromise and Acceptance

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on 'integrative couples therapy' as new and novel approach to helping married couples reconcile their differences; notes concept is exhaustively described and illustrated in new book, Reconcilable Differences, by Dr Andrew Christensen and late Dr Neil S Jacobson; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For John V. Cody, 77, an artist in Lynnfield, Mass., it has been two months and counting since his personal introduction to one of the most unpleasant and underpublicized rites of getting older: a bout of the shingles. At first the clustered blisters that sprouted on the left side of his chest, then spread to his back, were just an annoyance. Now the blisters are long healed, but they have left behind a squeezing, crushing pain ''like a medieval torture device,'' he said, that encases his chest and left upper arm, making sleep difficult and work impossible. Instead of doing the drawings he had planned to finish this winter, Mr. Cody is spending his time doodling caricatures of his shingles personified as a massive taloned monster gleefully crushing its victim's left side.

headline.main: Making Inroads in Fight Against Shingles Pain

docs.abstract: Slow progress is reported in fight against shingles; new research into the mechanisms of the pain are slowing enabling better treatments; researchers also seek older volunteers to help confirm a hunch that newly available vaccine for chickenpox, which is caused by same varicella-zoster virus, may not only prevent chickenpox in children but also the pain of shingles in adults; photos; graphs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Early in her memoir on living with diabetes, Lisa Roney describes a hike through the Great Smoky Mountains and her frustrating inability to keep pace with her group. Elevated blood sugar, probably from eating too much gorp, was making her lethargic and confused, and she had to keep sitting down to rest along the narrow trail. Only her best friend's older brother had the decency to hang back and ease her along, and the rest of the group teased her over his attention. But humiliating as their taunts were, Ms. Roney recalls, it was better to be seen as manipulative than medically flawed.

headline.main: In Memoirs, Diabetics Tell of Troubles and Triumphs

docs.abstract: Strains and triumphs of living with diabetes are revealed in memoirs written by Lisa Roney, Deb Butterfield, Andie Dominick; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: When Dr. Amanda J. Gruber, a Massachusetts psychiatrist, meets with patients, the last thing she wants to do is discourage them from exercising. She tells them to go to the gym and offers compelling reasons: ''It decreases depression. It decreases anxiety. It decreases the risk of osteoporosis.'' Then, she adds a caution: ''Don't get caught up in whole body-image thing.''

headline.main: An Ominous Obsession at Women's Gym

docs.abstract: Dr Amanda J Gruber, Massachusetts psychiatrist, finds that 50 of 75 female weightlifters interviewed said they had used potentially dangerous substances like anabolic steroids or ephedrine; finds that many had eating and body-image disorders (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: By the time most gallstones make their painful presence known, there are not always a lot of options. An estimated half a million Americans a year, mostly women, end up having to have their gallbladders removed in what is the most common operation in the nation, experts say. Now researchers using new, high-powered equipment report that they have photographed gallstones as they form, raising hope that a better understanding of their origins may help prevent them.
docs.abstract: Researchers using new, high-powered equipment photograph gallstones as they form, raising hopes that a better understanding of their origins may help prevent them (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Those who champion the low-fat vegetarian vegan diet have long made broad health claims for the regimen. Now one of the diet's biggest advocates is making a new claim; he says it can greatly reduce menstrual pain and the symptoms of premenstrual syndrome. Not all of the 33 women studied reported benefits, but most did, said Dr. Neal D. Barnard, the diet's advocate and the president of the Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine, which helped conduct the study. ''In some of them, it was quite profound,'' Dr. Barnard said.

headline.main: For Some, Vegan Diet Relieves PMS

docs.abstract: Researcher contends that low-fat vegetarian vegan diet can greatly reduce menstrual pain and symptoms of premenstrual syndrome (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A chart on Feb. 8 with the Personal Health column, about nuts, misstated the allergenic risk of nut oils. Most nut oil refined in the United States is free of protein, the allergen in nuts, and therefore does not cause problems for people with nut allergies. But oil extracted by certain methods, like the cold-pressed process, may still contain protein and can indeed pose a risk. Information is available from the Food Allergy Network at www.foodallergy.org or (703) 691-3179.
docs.abstract: Correction of Feb 8 chart about allergenic risk of nut oils

docs.lead_paragraph: Adults who like to think of America's young as a bunch of lazy, cigarette-packing television addicts may be disappointed by a major new study that finds that adolescents in the United States smoke and watch television less than those in many other industrialized nations. That still leaves lazy -- or, at least, sedentary -- and the study, conducted by the World Health Organization, finds that American teenagers exercise less than their peers elsewhere. And they eat more junk food.

headline.main: Youth Today: Not So Bad, by Comparison

docs.abstract: World Health Organization reports that American teenagers smoke and watch television less than those in many other industrialized nations, but that they also exercise less than their peers elsewhere and eat more junk food (S)
